meanings.definition: A loud and noisy outcry or protest.
meanings.sent1: The outroar of the crowd could be heard from far away.
meanings.sent2: The outroar of the protesters echoed through the streets.
meanings.sent3: The outroar of the children playing outside was music to my ears.
meanings.sent4: The outroar of the storm outside matched the turmoil in my mind.
meanings.sent5: The outroar of the waterfall was both beautiful and deafening.

meanings.definition: To make a loud and noisy outcry or protest.
meanings.sent1: She will outroar her disagreement if she feels strongly about it.
meanings.sent2: The fans will outroar their excitement when their team scores.
meanings.sent3: The cat will outroar its displeasure if you try to give it a bath.
meanings.sent4: The thunder will outroar any other sound during the storm.
meanings.sent5: The lion will outroar to establish dominance in the pride.
